intro: Abronia glauca, commonly known as the blueflower sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial shrub that typically reaches heights of 10–30 centimeters. The plant produces small, tubular blue or violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and gray-green, often covered in a fine layer of white hair.

It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils along the shoreline, often in areas with mild temperatures and moderate rainfall. This plant is commonly found in dunes and other coastal habitats where it can tolerate salt spray and wind. Its distribution is limited to these specific environments, making it a characteristic species of the California coast. Due to its restricted range, Abronia glauca is considered a rare and endemic plant in its native habitat.
